questions.question: For what is File Based Discovery used?
answers: A. To discover the checksum of a file and store it to track for changes
B. To discover the contents of flat files such as configuration files
C. To discover that file names conform to a defined naming standard
D. To discover file paths to recognize the signature of installed software

comments.content: A naming standard does not matter in discovery. However, the fastest way to find out the name of an application is to correlate its config file location to that of typical installations.

File-based Discovery probes execute a scan searching for specific file extensions or file names in paths that you configure. The resulting file information is returned in the probe payload. The sensor attempts to match the discovered files with installed software, using the file name, size, and version returned by the probe. File-based Discovery uses file signatures to detect software that might not have been registered.

questions.question: After running Discovery and viewing the ECC Queue tab, what are some of the displayed default fields? (Choose three.)

Hardware Models can have a one-to-many relationship with the following:
(Choose three.)

comments.content:
ACE.
Option B is incorrect because a hardware model has a one-to-one relationship with the manufacturer, as a hardware model is typically associated with a single manufacturer.

A,C,E is correct. Manufacturer can have a one-to-many relationship with Models but not the other way around.

https://docs.servicenow.com/bundle/xanadu-it-asset-management/page/product/product-catalog/concept/c_ModelCategories.html

A, C, E is correct.

If you look on the "cmdb_hardware_product_model" form, the manufacturer and owner fields is are reference fields and therefore can't have one-to-many relationships.

replies:
Change to B,D,E
confirmed in PDI again.

comments.content: A, C, E, confirmed on PDI

questions.question: Which choice best represents how to modify the functionality shown in this image?

comments.content: Configuration file tracking is available for patterns that discover applications. On the pattern, you can create tracked file definitions that specify the CI type to which the application CI belongs and the path of the configuration file. Specify as many tracked file definitions as needed. You can also specify whether you want to save the contents of configuration files so you can view and compare the contents of different versions.
B should be the correct answer
B should be the correct answer

questions.question: What pattern operation allows the transfer of a file from the MID Server to a target?
On the ECC Queue, sensor records have a Queue value of ___________ and probe records have a Queue value of ___________.

comments.content:
A. Input, Output

Discovery Course - Module 5
To determine whether a record is for a probe or a sensor, look at the value in the Queue column. Sensor records are in the input queue, and probe records are in the output queue

i asked chatgpt-On the ECC Queue, sensor records have a Queue value of **`output`** and probe records have a Queue value of **`input`**.--Yes, I am confident. 

In **ServiceNow**, the **ECC (External Communication Channel) Queue** is used for communication between the ServiceNow instance and external systems or processes. The **`input`** queue is used for incoming messages (like probe results from MID Servers), and the **`output`** queue is used for outgoing messages (like sensor triggers sent to the MID Server). 

- **Sensor records** typically have a queue value of **`output`** because they represent commands or triggers sent to the MID Server for further processing.  
- **Probe records** have a queue value of **`input`** because they are results or responses sent back to the ServiceNow instance for processing. 

Let me know if you need further clarification!

replies:
A is the answer. The link you just shared shows this:

"Probes and sensors
Probes and sensors are scripts that collect and process data on a host and then update the CMDB. More specifically, probes explore or investigate CIs on your network, and sensors parse the data returned from the probes."

Probes are the output and sensors are the input.

questions.question: In Discovery, what table associates an IP address and a credential?
In general, Discovery can provide which of the following kinds of application relationships? (Choose two.)

comments.content:
B -AND- D
(the question asks you to choose two.)

Application to Application Relationships:
Application discovery identifies which applications are being used in a given environment. It allows organizations to understand the relationships between different applications. By mapping these relationships, IT teams gain insights into how applications interact with each other, their dependencies, and their respective workloads12.
Host to Application Relationships:
Application discovery also helps establish relationships between hosts (servers) and applications. It provides visibility into which applications are installed on specific hosts. Understanding these relationships is essential for managing and optimizing application performance, security, and resource allocation1.
Therefore, the correct answers are B. application to application and D. host to application.

questions.question: Which of the following must be configured to allow a MID Server to access servers using WinRM? (Choose two.)
answers: A. JEA Properties set to True
B. MID Servers must be configured as a trusted source with DNS
C. MID Servers need to be added to the WinRM Group policy on the Servers
D. MID Server Parameters Add WinRM

comments.content: DNS trust is not a factor since IPs are used and not hostnames. WinRM has to be set up on the MID Server, and Active Directory has to allow WinRM use.

replies:
B is almost correct but DNS is not mentioned in documentation. It seems to be a trap word.
C & D in my opinion.

questions.question: Which ECC Queue message contains the XML payload returned from the MID Server?
Which of the following executes the osquery commands on agents to gather attribute details from a CI?

comments.content:
This guide says it is D.
https://www.servicenow.com/community/itom-articles/build-your-own-acc-v-inventory-module-check-definition/ta-p/2368617

Once the Check Type is defines you need a check definition that define the way of querying the end-device.  This could be done with scripts, commands or with the build in OSQuery (https://osquery.io/). ACC-V uses OSQuery for other data detection, and is maintained by the Agent. 

The good thing is that there is a predefined Check Definition to run OSQuery (util.osquery.agent) that you can take inspiration from.
The Disco training has a slide which states: Check Definitions executes the osquery command on agents.  verbatim..  I'm suggesting D.

I wanted to make a correction. I found the answer in Module 7 of the lab. If you watch that module at the portion where it talks about Check Definitions, it says word for word "executes the osquery command on agents." and "osquery commands are used to gather specific attribute details..."
That being said the correct answer is actually D. Check Definitions
I also believe it is C
replies: The answer is D not C.

comments.content:
Could be C

Check site number 2 in the link
https://www.servicenow.com/content/dam/servicenow-assets/public/en-us/doc-type/resource-center/data-sheet/ds-itom-acc.pdf
replies:
ACC also supports
OSQuery, allowing you to query hosts and run remediation commands on
demand or from ServiceNow workflows using the Automation Engine spoke
available on the ServiceNow Store.

questions.question: While discovering a new SNMP network device, which choice could cause the error “Active, couldn’t classify” to occur on a Discovery Status?
answers: A. A firewall blocking the communication between the MID Server and the target device.
C. SNMP only behavior is not configured.
D. An SNMP Classification must be updated or created for the new device.

comments.content:
The error message refers to a classification error.
If the SNMP credentials are incorrect (option B), the discovery attempt would fail completely when connecting to the device, but a classification error would not specifically occur.
From the self-paced learning troubleshooting module on Classification, it says that the classifier for SNMP is missing if you encounter this error
Based on the troubleshooting module of the self-paced training, the example they gave stated that this is the result of a classifier not existing for the specific CI.

I would say B based on this:
https://support.servicenow.com/kb?id=kb_article_view&sysparm_article=KB0535236

From this community thread D is correct, but documentation would be better to be completely sure.
https://www.servicenow.com/community/itom-forum/unable-to-discover-snmp-devices-active-could-t-classify/m-p/931929/page/3

questions.question: The deletion strategy is set to ‘Mark as absent’ for related Disk CIs discovered via the Linux Server pattern. If a related Disk CI is discovered during the Linux Server discovery and then the same related Disk CI is not found the next time the Linux Server is discovered, the following will happen:
answers: A. The Disk Status CI (install_status) is set to Absent.
B. The Disk CI Operational Status (operational_status) is set to Non-Operational.
C. The Linux Server CI Operational Status (operational_status) is set to Non-Operational.
D. The Linux Server CI Status (install_status) is set to Absent.

questions.question: Which of the choices best describes a tabular variable in a discovery pattern?
answers: C. Each cell is a CI attribute
D. Each cell is a scalar variable

comments.content:
D is correct 
https://docs.servicenow.com/bundle/vancouver-it-operations-management/page/product/service-mapping/reference/r_PatternVariables.html

A variable can be:
Scalar: A single string
Tabular: A table, where each cell is a scalar variable.
Vector: A single, unnamed column with as many rows as needed

questions.question: When configuring the MID Server Service Settings, which of the following is not a valid MID Server name?

comments.content:
C is correct
https://support.servicenow.com/kb?id=kb_article_view&sysparm_article=KB0744416

MID Server naming
The MID server name cannot start with "mid.server"

If it does, the the problem with inserting ECC records in the ECC queue fails to insert properly.

This is because the agent field in the ECC queue will append "mid.server" to the beginning of the MID server name. This causes the records in the ecc queue to be incorrect and fails to send commands to the MID server.

questions.question: Which one of the following is not used in a horizontal discovery pattern?

comments.content: I want to again correct my first answer. I think the correct answer is actually conectivity section. When you go to the pattern and select Infrastructure as the type, it shows two sections the "Identification section" and the "extension section". When you select application, it show both of those as well as a "Connection Section" not "Connectivity" I think this is a trick question.

B is correct. 
https://docs.servicenow.com/bundle/vancouver-it-operations-management/page/product/service-mapping/task/t_DefineConnecSectionPatDef.html

Procedure

Navigate to All > Pattern Designer > Discovery Patterns and open the required pattern from the pattern list.
The pattern must be of the Application type.

In the Connectivity Section, click New.
Note: The Connectivity Section is greyed out if the pattern cannot be edited for Service Mapping.

questions.question: How do you create relationships between CIs in a horizontal pattern?
answers: A. Relationships are created automatically for each successful connection section.
B. By using the Create Connections operation.
C. By using the Create Relation/Reference operation.
D. Relationships cannot be created via patterns.

comments.content:
As part of creating or modifying a discovery pattern, you can use the Relation and/or Reference condition to create relationships and references between CIs and their related items. This operation is relevant for both infrastructure and application patterns that Discovery uses for horizontal discovery.
https://docs.servicenow.com/bundle/washingtondc-it-operations-management/page/product/service-mapping/task/t_CreateARelationshipAndReference.html
